Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, part 34, Heaven of YÄma, part 20
There is another teaching for ká¹£atriya kings, the twenty-second, which they should diligently practice, accomplish, and be in accord with, for the benefit of both the present and future lives.
The twenty-second is having firm and solid friends.
A king with firm and solid friends will think well and act well, be a king for a long time, be free from faults, and cannot be destroyed by others.
Just as a tree with many roots grows long and deep, firmly and well established, unshakable, and cannot be destroyed by the wind.

Just as that firm tree cannot be destroyed by the wind, so too is the king. Knowing that his friends are firm and solid, with a good mind and good intentions, he is loved by all and respected by everyone.
In worldly matters, firm and solid virtues and good friends have thirteen kinds of virtues complete.
What are the thirteen?
First, if the king has evil, they can make him pure.
Second, they can do the most difficult tasks for the king.
Third, they have wisdom. If their good friend has another good friend, they will make them friends.
Fourth, they are completely sincere. They know all the wealth and goods of their good friend.
Fifth, they are completely intent. They know the beneficial matters of their good friend and diligently carry them out.
Sixth, they are relaxed. If they suddenly meet, they do not examine their deportment.
Seventh, they are ultimate. If they encounter misfortune or even lose their lives, they will not abandon [their friend].
Eighth, they are satisfying. They do as their heart desires, according to their needs.
Ninth, they are not secretive. They do not hide anything in their home, and they are not stingy in giving according to their needs.
Tenth, they have the same mind. If they see that their good friend has many complete [virtues], they give rise to joy.
Eleventh, if they encounter suffering, they share the suffering together. Even if greatly angry, their minds do not change;
Whatever food they have, they all eat together and play together.
Twelfth, they do not seek with inferior faculties for things they have;
If they have their own things, they do not suffer to give.
Thirteenth, if they know the good and bad news in the household up to quarrels, they tell all such things without reservation or difficulty;
The affairs of their own household up to quarrels, they also tell all.ğŸ”½Such are the thirteen virtues of good friends. Such virtuous good friends are then the world.

Thus, the world is endowed with the thirteen virtues of good friends. If the king accomplishes one, he has great power, let alone many. Therefore, the wise king should diligently gather such good friends.
If the king diligently associates with such good friends, all his beloved activities will be accomplished.
Moreover, because of good friends, one can also accomplish the supramundane path.
To put it briefly, there are ten merits of a fully endowed good friend.
What are the ten?
First, they can stop unwholesome conduct;
second, they can teach one to practice giving;
third, they can teach one to uphold precepts and observe precepts;
fourth, they can show wisdom and teach one to cultivate wisdom;
fifth, with a good mind, they can stop one from associating with bad friends;
sixth, with right faith, they can show the fruits of karma;
seventh, if they see one confused and on a wrong path, they can teach one to abide in the right path;
eighth, if they see one violating precepts, they can help eliminate them;
ninth, they can teach one to make offerings to one's parents;
tenth, they can always constantly instruct and admonish.
Such ten kinds of supramundane good friends can protect one from all evil paths, just like parents.
Firmly maintaining good friends, always towards good friends.
If there are good friends, do not give rise to a sense of superiority.
Such good friends are not in the present world, but in the future world. Therefore, the king should firmly maintain good friends.

If the king is like this, firmly maintaining good friends, then due to the causes and conditions of cultivating good deeds and merits, in the present world he will always obtain happiness, always have benefits, be able to protect the country, be able to protect himself, be praised by good people, and when the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in a good realm, in the heavens, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of firmly maintaining good friends and the causes and conditions of good deeds.

Moreover, there is one more principle for the ká¹£atriya king, the twenty-third, which he should diligently abandon and accomplish in accordance with it, benefiting both the present and future worlds.
The twenty-third is this: namely, not befriending those who are of no benefit.
Those who are of no benefit are all those who deceive and delude others.
Do not associate with gamblers or those who lead others to evil.
If one has evil thoughts and acts upon them, associating with such people will bring great harm and great loss.
The greatest loss is deception.
There are two kinds of deception:
First, private;
Second, public.
The public kind refers to various deceptions such as gambling.
The private kind refers to disguising one's appearance and attire like an evil person, deceiving those who do not know the truth into thinking one is good.

Such people are embraced by non-Buddhists and are thorns among non-Buddhists. They deceive their own relatives and others, are not afraid of the afterlife, and appear outwardly virtuous. They are actually great thieves.
Such people should not even be seen or spoken to, let alone befriended and considered acquaintances.
Good people should abandon them.
They are unable to benefit themselves, let alone others.
The king should abandon such unwholesome friends and unhelpful companions, not associate with deceptive people, and not associate with gamblers.
Such people should not be acquainted with, but one should act with right mindfulness and right thought.

If the king associates with wholesome friends and is influenced by wholesome friends, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always obtain happiness and benefit in the present world, be able to protect the country and himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the good realms, in the heavenly world as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
It is due to the cause of not associating with unhelpful friends.
'There is another principle for ká¹£atriya kings, the twenty-fourth, which they should diligently practice and accomplish, benefiting both the present and future lives.
Twenty-fourth, namely, not being moved by anger or joy.

If a ká¹£atriya king can control anger and joy, his kingdom will be firm and unbreakable, all the people of the country will be diligent and happy, not giving rise to aversion, and no one will be able to destroy or take advantage of him.

If the king is not angry, he acts with consideration, not without consideration, and does not demote people without cause, and does not promote officials or give them wealth and benefits without cause.
Because he is not angry, his secret words are not revealed.
He does not promote or demote others without cause;
in places of joy, his mind is not uplifted;
such a king has a true mind in his body, does not do evil, does not associate with evil people, and has an impartial and respectful mind.
That king, in this way, is not moved by anger or joy in worldly matters and thus attains peace.
How does he, moreover, not be moved by anger or joy in the supramundane path and thus attain peace?
If the king does not get angry, he can uphold the single defilement of birth and death;
If the king is not pleased, he can uphold the defilement of power.
That king can thus uphold the defilement of power and the defilement of birth and death.
If a person can uphold these two defilements, he can uphold the defilement of the power of delusion.

If the king can thus uphold these three defilements, with firm intention and wisdom, and a determined mind, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always experience happiness and benefit in the present and future worlds, be able to protect the country and his own self, be praised by good people, and after the body's collapse and the end of life, be reborn in the celestial realm of the Heaven of YÄma as a king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of the good causes and conditions of not being moved by anger and joy.
The ká¹£atriya king has another duty, the twenty-fifth, which he should diligently practice, accomplish, and be in accord with, for the benefit of both the present and future.
The twenty-fifth is this: namely, not being attached to the two dharmas of food and drink, and not being greedy for too much.
Why is this?
If one is greedy for food and drink, it will hinder the king, because one always thinks about food and drink being in the stomach.
The people of the country and the left and right armies will give rise to contempt, thinking like this:
The mind of that king is the same as that of an animal, only thinking about food and drink, without any other thoughts or thoughts of other duties.

Always like this, greedy for food and drink, the mind always delights in the taste of food and drink, so one does not contemplate the Dharma and non-Dharma, cannot consider and contemplate matters of the country, does not contemplate people, cannot subdue all the left and right inner and outer armies, cannot bestow ranks and titles in a timely manner to all the ministers and people of the country, and does not know theè½»é‡ of what should be done.
The wealth of that king will only decrease.
Because of the decrease in wealth, there will be less wealth.
Because of the lack of wealth, food and drink will be exhausted.
Because of the lack of food and drink, everyone despises them.
Because of greed for food and drink, they become impoverished.
Greed for too much food and drink, not restraining oneself, is like this, obstructing worldly benefits.
How does it further obstruct the supramundane?

It means that the mind is attached to enjoying too much food and drink, always loving various flavors, not contemplating correctly, unable to think of the body, unable to think of feelings, unable to think of the mind, unable to think of dharmas, unable to think of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, and unable to think of everything else.
In this way, attachment to the realm of food and drink is no different from animals.

Therefore, one should rely on the principle of reality, eat and drink appropriately, speak appropriately according to one's practice, purify the faculties, move appropriately, and contemplate the correct path - the body, feelings, mind, dharmas, suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path.
In this way, the mind is well-tamed in the Dharma, able to think and remember.
Because the mind is rightly mindful, the faculties become pure, and the appropriate food and drink make the body well-regulated.
Because the body is well-regulated, the mind is also well-regulated.
Because the mind is well-regulated, one is able to think of wholesome dharmas.
Therefore, one should not be attached to various flavors.
If one takes food and drink into the body and regulates it appropriately, it will be peaceful and comfortable, and one should always practice in accordance with the Dharma.
In this way, the king is able to subdue the mind, the mind is rightly mindful, and because the mind is rightly mindful, he is able to do wholesome deeds.

If the king is not greedy for food and drink in this way, the causes and conditions of his merits will enable him to always obtain peace and benefit in the present world, to protect the country and his own body, to be praised by good people, and when his body perishes and his life ends, the wholesome deeds he cultivated will be like a fragrant wind, and he will be born in the heavens, becoming the king of the YÄma Heaven.
It is because of the good causes and conditions of not being greedy for the two flavors of food and drink.
The king should also cultivate the twenty-sixth principle, which is good contemplation.
Good contemplation is the cause of all worldly and transcendent happiness.
Why is this?
Because the mind is the root of all dharmas.ğŸ”½If one contemplates well, one will always obtain supreme happiness in this life and the next.
If one contemplates well, one will not commit any faults.
One should think like this:
The defilements of greed, anger, and delusion lead to evil paths. I should eliminate them.

I should eliminate the defilement of greed with the contemplation of impurity, the defilement of anger with the contemplation of loving-kindness and compassion, and the defilement of delusion with the contemplation of wisdom.
In this way, one can eliminate them through good contemplation, not through evil thoughts.
If one has evil thoughts, one cannot accomplish worldly dharmas;
only with good thoughts can one accomplish them.
Therefore, one should know that all dharmas are accomplished by good thoughts.

If the king thus contemplates with a good mind, due to the merit and virtue of this cause and condition, he will always obtain peace and happiness in the present world, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and his own body, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the cause of good thoughts and good karma.
The ká¹£atriya king has another dharma, the twenty-seventh, which he should diligently practice and accomplish, bringing benefit to both the present and future lives.
The twenty-seventh is: not waiting for the right time, but acting calmly.
If one acts to bring benefit to the world or to transcend the world, if one waits a long time to act, then it cannot be done.
If one cannot do something but still does it, then it will not be accomplished.
It is like having an illness that is not quickly treated, but is treated after a long time, then it will be difficult to treat;
Because it is difficult to treat, it can kill a person.

In the same way, there are also countless practices that should be done quickly, but if one does them after a long time, they will be difficult to do, hard to do, and impossible to do. In this way, they can obstruct the supramundane path.
Minor afflictions are also like that illness. Because they are not quickly treated, the afflictions are not eliminated;
Because they are not eliminated, one enters the evil destinies.
This is the great harm of doing things after a long time. In this way, it obstructs the supramundane path.

Because minor afflictions are not eliminated in a timely manner, they gradually increase, just like a poisonous sprout. After a long time, they increase and can burn the entire body, causing beings to fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals. Therefore, one should not wait leisurely until a long time later to do things.
Such a king, or any other person, whether a monk or a layperson, whether wealthy or poor, should not wait until later to act.
If a person waits until later to act, they will quickly bring about their own decline and distress, and it will take a long time to eliminate, destroy, or cut off that decline.
Because of not cutting it off, one will bring about one's own decline.
If a person does not wait until later to act, they will quickly lose and be uprooted.
Such a person, because they do not have that fault, will ultimately attain happiness and abide in the worldly and transcendent paths.
If such a person's fault arises at the beginning, they will be able to eliminate it, like a poisonous sprout that is seen and removed as soon as it appears.
That poisonous sprout is a metaphor for afflictions, which, if allowed to grow for a long time, will increase and give rise to many faults.
Therefore, if one cuts off the faults that arise from the beginning, it is true knowledge, and one attains peace and happiness, and that person is always joyful.

If the king does not wait for a later time to act carefully in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always obtain happiness and always have benefits in the present world, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, that person will always be joyful, and after the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in a good realm, in the celestial world, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of the causes and conditions of good karma that do not wait for a later time to act carefully.
'There is another principle for the ká¹£atriya king, the twenty-eighth, which he should diligently practice and accomplish, benefiting both the present and future.
The twenty-eighth is called benefiting the country with the Dharma, not with what is not the Dharma.
That Dharma king benefits himself and is able to benefit others.
Self-benefit means that if a king upholds the precepts and can protect the country, it is not due to not upholding the precepts.
Benefiting others means seeing people who do not follow the Dharma and causing them to abide in the Dharma.
The king thus properly protects the country, and because of protecting the country, the three of Dharma, wealth, and fame are all obtained together.
Since he can thus cause others to rely on the Dharma, how much more so would he himself not follow the Dharma?
Such a king will then obtain wealth.
How does he obtain wealth?
It means that in the country, he definitely takes one-sixth of all wealth.
Therefore, the country becomes greatly wealthy, due to proper protection.
If the country is greatly wealthy and the king has an urgent matter, all the people, out of love for the king, know that the king has an urgent need for wealth and will all give him much.
This is the second merit and virtue that the king possesses and accomplishes.
Such a king rightly protects the country. The left and right armies respect and love the king, and his good reputation spreads in all directions.

If the king is like this, with Dharma, wealth, and fame combined and complete, he will always obtain happiness in the present world and always have benefits. He can protect the country and protect himself. He is praised by good people. When the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in the good realms, in the heavens, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the causes of good karma for benefiting oneself and others.
'There is another principle for the ká¹£atriya king, the twenty-ninth, which he should diligently practice and accomplish. It will bring benefits in both the present and future lives.
The twenty-ninth is to always practice the ten wholesome courses of action.
Those ten wholesome courses of action have the foremost blissful retribution. In brief, there are three kinds: bodily, verbal, and mental.
Bodily there are three:
killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
The mouth has four:
Lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and frivolous speech.
The mind has three:
Greed, hatred, and wrong views.
These ten kinds of unwholesome courses of action, when inverted, are called the ten wholesome courses of action, called the path of wisdom, called the right path.

The unwholesome courses of action have no wisdom, the wholesome path has wisdom, therefore it is called the path of wisdom, leading people to be born in the heavens, and in sequence, reaching nirvana.
Such a king himself is able to abide, and also causes others in the army to abide. Such a king is like a parent to all beings, able to reach nirvana.
According to his own wishes, he attains all paths.

Such a king, all that he thinks of is accomplished, always protected by the gods, without fear of swords, enemies, and so forth, all lands are always not destroyed or chaotic, and all five grains ripen well in a timely manner.
Just like the timely and harmonious adjustment of the sun and moon in the heavens, universally illuminating everything, the country's resources are all complete, and there are many people.
When the king thus righteously protects the country, later, when impermanence comes, his body perishes, and his life ends, he is reborn in the good destinies, in the heavenly realms.
What karmic retribution does he receive?
What kind of bliss does he experience?
In brief, in the Heaven of YÄma, because of not killing, the heavenly lifespan is then long, with lower, middle, and upper [levels]. Such is the heavenly lifespan.

In the six desire heavens, because of not stealing, one is greatly wealthy in the heavens, replete with the seven treasures, with various delightful gardens, forests, and mountain peaks, playing and enjoying pleasures in such places.
Because of not engaging in sexual misconduct, the heavenly maidens do not all go to other heavenly sons, and until they retrogress and lose their lives, they do not go near [them].
Those heavenly maidens are all upright and beautiful, with excellent complexions and sublime radiance, delightful to the eyes and the mind.
If one engages in sexual misconduct, when reborn in the heavens, the celestial maidens will also consort with other gods.

In this way, the results of various karmic retributions are accomplished. Such bodily good karmic actions, well-protected and not transgressed, happily cultivated and done much, lead to rebirth in the heavens and the experience of heavenly blissful retributions.
Next, the second is the four good karmic actions of speech, happily cultivated and done much, leading to rebirth in the heavens.
What karmic actions of speech lead to rebirth in the heavens?
What blissful retributions are experienced?
It refers to cultivating the four kinds of correct speech and precepts.

Because of not lying, one speaks truthful, pleasant, and various kinds of real words. At all times, one always speaks the most wonderful words. Whatever one says, one is happy with those words. Because of not lying, whatever one says is accomplished.
Because of not engaging in divisive speech, the armies one possesses are always indestructible and always follow and make offerings.
Because of not speaking harshly, one always hears beautiful and delightful sounds of singing, dancing, playing, and laughter, the most pleasing and delightful sounds.
Because of not engaging in frivolous speech, one always speaks meaningfully, and all the gods love and trust one's words. One attains such karmic rewards of speech in the heavens.
What are the karmic rewards of the mind? What pleasures does one experience in the heavens?
Because of non-greed, one obtains everything one thinks of, and once obtained, one does not lose it. Other gods cannot encroach upon it, and one enjoys it alone.
This karmic reward is due to the karma of non-greed.

Because of non-hatred, all the gods love one, and one has the most beautiful and delightful appearance.ğŸ”½Because of not holding wrong views, one obtains everything one seeks, just as one seeks it, without change or difference.
One obtains everything one thinks of, and never fails to obtain it, always obtaining it completely.
Thus, in brief, the results of the ten wholesome courses of action are explained.
'If one gives, one will obtain superior rewards.
Because of giving, wealth and happiness increase.
Because of superior wisdom, one surpasses all gods.

All pleasant feelings are rooted in this. If one foolishly enjoys them, they are not true enjoyment. Because the mind is free, because of the power of the field of blessings, because of the freedom of time, because of the freedom of objects, and because of the power of faith and understanding.
Because of freedom, there is a wholesome karma that also leads to rebirth in the heavens, and there are sentient beings who enter nirvana, let alone rebirth in the heavens.
Such karmic results are extremely subtle. Who does not know them? One is confused about karmic results. Because of being confused about karmic results, one enters hell.

As explained, if the king practices the ten wholesome courses of action, or if the people of the country or the king's troops do so because of the king, they all practice the ten wholesome courses of action.

If the king cultivates these ten wholesome actions in this way, the merit and virtue will enable him to always experience peace and happiness in the present life, to always have benefits, to protect the country and his own self, to be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, to be reborn in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the cause of practicing the ten wholesome actions.
The ká¹£atriya king has a third set of ten dharmas, the thirtieth, which he should diligently cultivate and practice, to benefit both the present and future lives.
The thirtieth is called faith in causes.
A king or minister who has faith in causes will not be confused about karmic retribution, will always be mindful, and will not be negligent in his conduct towards sense objects.
The cause is called the cause of the seed of the fruit, and the conditions are the complete and harmonious combination of time and place.
That is called the cause of faith.
If one has faith in the cause, one will also have faith in the effect. With such a true understanding of cause and effect, one will not do evil deeds.
Just as seeds are the cause of sprouts, in the same way, due to the cause of seeing the truth and having faith, one does not become confused about karmic retribution.

Such karma, whether good or bad, causes the continuity of birth and death to continue without interruption, and various kinds of suffering and happiness cause sentient beings to be reborn in various places, transmigrating in the intermediate state.
Thus, in the intermediate state, one continues to transmigrate in the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, gods, and humans.
There are three kinds of practices:
1. Meritorious actions;
2. Sinful actions;
3. Immovable actions, which refer to the practices of the four dhyanas.
Those meritorious actions are the cause for becoming a god or human;
those sinful actions are the cause for becoming a hell being and so forth;
those immovable actions are the cause for becoming a form realm being.
If the king only understands the causes within those three realms, that king will not become confused in the wilderness of birth and death.
In this way, all of this is the cause and effect within conditioned existence.
The king believes in cause and effect, and past offenses cannot destroy it. Because he is able to fear past offenses, he does not create unwholesome karma, but always creates wholesome karma.

If the king is like this, because of believing in the power of cause and effect and merit, he will always obtain happiness in the present world, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he will be born in a good realm, in the heavens, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
It is because of believing in causes and conditions and wholesome karma.
The supreme teaching for all sentient beings is to believe in causes and conditions.
Therefore, the king should diligently cultivate and uphold this teaching, which is to believe in causes and conditions.
Moreover, there is another teaching for the ká¹£atriya king, the thirty-first, which he should diligently cultivate and accomplish, benefiting both the present and future lives.
The thirty-first is to make offerings to the gods.
For what reasons should one make offerings to those gods?
Because of good karmic actions, one is reborn in the heavens with great spiritual powers. If I create unwholesome karmic paths, they can restrain me.
Whether at night or during the day, I always make offerings. All that is done can be subdued, and they can show what is good or bad in dreams.
When all countries are not beneficial, they can protect and cause one to enter the good Dharma.
Those heavens can thus restrain what is unwholesome, and whether at night or during the day, they can always protect, just as parents with immeasurable skillful means protect in various ways.
One should make offerings to the heavens, for they can create goodness.
Therefore, the king makes offerings to those heavens. Because of loving the Dharma, he abandons evil karma, does not harm others, and is not of wrong views.
He does not have such an intention:
Apart from the heavens, there are no karmic actions. These heavens create.
All worlds do not have such a mind:
All suffering and happiness are created by the heavens.
They do not have such a mind:
'Worshiping the gods in this way is for my own benefit and will not go to waste.'
This is not slandering cause and effect, nor is it a mind of wrong views. Because the king worships the gods in this way, he obtains the offerings of others.

If the king always worships the gods in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always obtain peace and benefit in the present world, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the good realms, in the heavens of the Heaven of YÄma.
It is because of the good causes and conditions of worshipping the gods.
'Moreover, there is one more of the thirty-two things that a ká¹£atriya king should do.
This is what a king should do, accomplishing what is appropriate, benefiting both the present and future worlds.
The thirty-second is always properly protecting the country.
A king who properly protects the country and follows the practice of the Dharma is like a parent, giving fearlessness to all who are afraid.
Because of giving fearlessness, good dharmas increase day and night, and all the troops respect and love him, never leaving his side.
The people in the country either offer wealth or praise him, calling him a good king.
Sometimes day and night, he always thinks of wanting to make that person attain peaceful and happy bliss.
Because that king benefits all sentient beings in this way, therefore it causes the king's sovereignty to increase.
Because of having much sovereignty, the five grains ripen, the country increases, and all the troops increase.
The elders in the country wish for the king's flourishing.
That such a king righteously protects the country, and the three of Dharma, wealth, and fame increase day by day, harmoniously corresponding.

If the king thus righteously protects the country, benefits the country at all times, is free from anger and greed, due to the causes and conditions of his merits, he will always obtain happiness and benefits in the present world, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be reborn in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven,
because of the causes and conditions of the good karma of protecting the country.
The thirty-third principle that a ká¹£atriya king should practice, which is suitable and beneficial for both the present and future lives,
is to always righteously protect his wife and children.
Because of protecting his wife and children, his wife and children obtain happiness. The king or great minister has immeasurable merit and many kinds of merit that accumulate and increase.
If he has wealth and possessions, he does not begrudge giving them to his wife and children, no matter what they are or when they are needed.
If one gives wealth, food and drink, bedding, clothing, or holds and embraces them, speaks lovingly and trusts them, causing their minds to be joyful, and gives them fearlessness.
According to one's ability, one gives to one's wife and children.
One obtains blessings in the house, and creates immeasurable kinds of blessings in the house. This protection of wife and children has great blessings.
If there are people who have no compassionate mind, or who are greedy and do not love their wife and children.
The mind of those people is worse than that of evil beasts who kill and eat meat, or eat feces and other animals.

If a person is unable to leave the household life and abide in the Dharma, that person should properly protect their wife and children according to their ability and share, and allow them to obtain happiness.
If one has the ability but has no compassionate mind and does not protect one's wife and children, such a person is not called a layperson and is not called one who has left the household life.
Therefore, one should give material things and other objects as charity, and teach them to uphold the precepts.

If the king or great ministers can make their wives and children receive precepts and observe precepts, teach them to be generous, teach them to cultivate wisdom, and further protect their happiness in order, according to their ability,
the king or great ministers will enjoy happiness for a long time and have a long lifespan.

If the king protects his wives and children in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always obtain happiness and benefit in the present world, be able to protect the country and his own body, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the causes and conditions of the good karma of protecting wives and children.
There is another principle that the ká¹£atriya king should diligently practice and accomplish, which brings benefit in both the present and future lives.
The thirty-fourth is called always cultivating wisdom.
Cultivating wisdom is called the cessation of all suffering and the escape from all causes of birth and death.
If one can definitely cultivate wisdom, it is good.
That wisdom is called:
For those who enter great darkness, fall into darkness, and experience immeasurable kinds of harm, it is like a lamp that illuminates;
Provisions for the wilderness and dangerous paths of birth and death;
Eyes for the blind;
Strength for the weak;
Companions for the friendless;
Saviors for the helpless;
